Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: The Norrona Project: An International Collaboration for Sustained Studies of the Meridional Overturning Circulation between Denmark, the Faroes and Iceland
Award.AbstractNarration:
The presence of and flow of warm salty water across the northern North Atlantic plays a key role in shaping the mild climate of central and northern Europe. This flow is in large measure controlled by enormous heat losses in the Nordic Seas that transform this water into very dense water that eventually spill back out into the deep North Atlantic. Since 2008, the flow of North Atlantic Water into the Nordic Seas has been measured where it passes through natural choke points: the Faroe-Shetland Channel (FSC) and the Iceland-Faroe Ridge (IFR). The measurements come from a shipboard acoustic Doppler current profiler (ADCP) that scans currents at high horizontal resolution along the track of the high-seas ferry M/F Norröna. While this has been a tremendous success, during rough weather in the winter bubbles are swept down and interfere with the instrument. To mitigate this problem, the instrument was recently moved further aft to the skeg, where fewer bubbles are expected. This project will allow the researchers to assess the improvement in data quality, and participate in the operation of the instrument and scientific analyses for another two years over which the operation will be handed over to scientists at the Institute of Marine Research (IMR) in Bergen, Norway and at Faroes Marine Research Institute.

The Iceland-Faroe-Scotland ridge separates two large and distinctly different water mass systems (the North Atlantic and the Arctic Mediterranean) that communicate through warm, salty inflow and dense water outflow through the deep gaps in the ridge. The inflow is quantified with these ADCP current profiles, coupled with temperature profiles from XBTs deployed automatically at selected sites from the Automated eXpendable Instrument System (AXIS) on the same vessel. On shorter time scales exchange is likely wind-driven, while on longer time scales (seasonal and longer) buoyancy loss must be of paramount importance. With sustained and improved Norröna monitoring of the inflows and moored ADCPs monitoring the outflow through the deep gaps (a Faroes-Norway program), one can examine in considerable detail the space-time response of these fluxes to time-varying atmospheric forcing including the well-known North-Atlantic Oscillation.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Long before the advent of modern oceanography Europeans were well aware of the warm Gulf Stream and its importance to the climate of Europe and Scandinavia. Thus, oceanographers have for many years had programs in place to measure the flow of warm water toward the Nordic Seas across the Greenland - Iceland - Scotland ridge. They have contributed enormously to our knowledge of these fluxes, but it has been an ongoing challenge due to the multiple and variable pathways across the ridge rendering it difficult to assess how this flow varies over time. About 90% of the warm water enters the Nordic Seas through two passages between Iceland, the Faroes, and Scotland, but both the amounts and the proportions vary, and these are not easy to capture with a limited number of moorings or hydrographic sections. In this project we sought to circumvent that limitation by scanning the currents from a vessel in regular traffic across both openings. While this approach cannot resolve temporal variability in any detail, it can capture the spatial structure of the currents not possible by any other means. 

Our approach was to equip the high-seas ferry, MS Norr?na, with a hull-mounted acoustic Doppler current profiler (ADCP) to profile ocean currents from the surface down to about 500-600 m. The ADCP measures currents relative to the ship. To correct for the ship's movement, we use the global positioning system (GPS) to determine its exact speed and heading. When these are taken into account water speed over the bottom can be determined to 0.01 ms-1 accuracy. The program started in 2006, but bubbles entrained underneath the vessel proved to be a major problem. It wasn't until 2009 after the installation a of fairing for the ADCP that we obtained significantly improved data return. 

An early, unexpected finding of the Norr?na project was the character of the flow south on the eastern side of the Faroe Plateau (in the Faroe-Shetland Channel, FSC). This current was well-known, but neither its strength nor variability. It has now been given the name Southern Faroe Current. The principal product of this project has been to provide an accurate multi-year average of mass, heat and salt flux exchange between the North Atlantic and the Nordic Seas with estimates of seasonal variability. Transport between Iceland and the Faroes is nearly independent of time of year whereas flow through the FSC shows a clear maximum in winter. 

 

A major outcome of this study is the growing recognition that this flow into the Nordic Seas comprises close to one half of the total Atlantic meridional overturning circulation (AMOC). The other half of the AMOC cools to intermediate depths and turns back south in the subpolar Irminger and Labrador Seas. We know this thanks to other programs that have monitored the AMOC at other latitudes. One such program involved a similar vessel-based ADCP operation. This freighter, the Nuka Arctica, operated between Greenland and Denmark. Through repeat sampling over several years it was possible to obtain an accurate estimate of the strength of the AMOC between Cape Farewell and Scotland. These Nuka Arctica and Norr?na routes encompass a ~106 km2 area. The difference in volume, heat and freshwater fluxes across these two routes reveal clearly that the AMOC has two overturning branches, one in the subpolar North Atlantic, and one that continues into the Nordic Seas. Both the subpolar and the Nordic Seas branches play an important role with respect to European climate, but during glacial times only the subpolar part of the AMOC remains active, the Nordic Seas branch was shut down; we know this from paleoclimate studies of ocean sediments.

Analysis of the Norr?na ADCP data continues. Already, they have contributed to the discovery that the deep flow south through the FSC banks up against the Scotland slope and not against the Faroe slope as was previously thought. Another study, stimulated by the Norr?na effort, involved an analysis of hydrographic data in two quiet regions spanning the Nordic Seas inflow. It was found that on decadal time scales transport into the Nordic Seas varies in tight synchrony with the Atlantic Multidecadal Variability. In fact, the fit is so tight that there is no evidence for a secular trend or long-term change in transport; it appears to be quite stable. Indeed, one may ask why it is so stable given the enormous warming presently underway in the Nordic Seas and Arctic Ocean. In light thereof it behooves us to keep a close watch on potential changes in ocean circulation. For this reason, there is considerable interest in maintaining the Norr?na operation. It will continue under Norwegian auspices.
